title: Data Warngling I
text:
Four Principles:

Reuse existing data structures.

The Data Frame

Compose simple functions with the pipe.

|>

Embrace functional programming.

Clear separate of data structure and functions.

Design for humans.

It should be readable!

title: Data Warngling I
text:
About dplyr

library(tidyverse)   # includes dplyr



The "dplyr" package in R is a fundamental tool for data manipulation, forming a core component of the tidyverse suite of packages.
It provides a consistent set of ‚Äúverbs‚Äù or functions designed to simplify common data wrangling tasks with data frames and tibbles (an enhanced data frame structure).

title: Data Warngling I
text:
dplyr verbs



slice()
select()
filter()
mutate()
arrange()
summarize()
group_by()



All of these have a data frame as the first argument.




All of these produce a data frame as output.




Within the function, you can simply refer to columns names unquoted.

title: Data Warngling II
text:
Agenda

Two big ideas today:

Data Pipelines
Grouped Operations

title: Data Warngling II
text:
library(tidyverse)

wizards <- data.frame(
  name = c("Harry", "Bellatrix", "Hermione", "Draco"),
  house = c("Gryffindor", "Slytherin", "Gryffindor",  "Slytherin"),
  height = c(1.78, 1.57, 1.65, 1.75),
  spells = c(60, 75, 70, 55)
)

Using base R data frame subsetting, create from wizards ‚Ä¶

The average height of characters from Gryffindor.


Let‚Äôs look at three ways to solve this.

title: Data Warngling II
text:
Nesting

summarize(filter(wizards, house == "Gryffindor"), mean(height))



  mean(height)
1        1.715







Must be read from the inside out üëé
Hard to keep track of arguments üëé



All in one line of code üëç
Only refer to one data frame üëç

title: Data Warngling II
text:
Step-by-step

wizards2 <- filter(wizards, house == "Gryffindor")
summarize(wizards2, mean(height))



  mean(height)
1        1.715







Have to repeat data frame names üëé
Creates unnecessary objects üëé



Stores intermediate objects üëç
Can be read from top to bottom üëç

title: Data Warngling II
text:
Data Pipelines in R




2016:
"magrittr" introduces %>%

2021:

R now provides a simple native forward pipe syntax |>. The simple form of the forward pipe inserts the left-had side as the first argument in the right-hand side call.

title: Data Warngling II
text:
Using the Pipe Operator

wizards

title: Data Warngling II
Data Warngling II
text:
Using the Pipe Operator

wizards |>
  filter(house == "Gryffindor") |> 
  summarize(mean(height))



  mean(height)
1        1.715







ü§∑



Can be read like an English paragraph üëç
Only type the data once üëç
No leftover objects üëç

title: Data Warngling II
text:
Understanding your pipeline
It‚Äôs good practice to understand the output of each line by breaking the pipe.






wizards |> 
  select(house) |> 
  filter(mean(height))



Error in `filter()`:
‚Ñπ In argument: `mean(height)`.
Caused by error:
! object 'height' not found




wizards |> 
  select(house)



       house
1 Gryffindor
2  Slytherin
3 Gryffindor
4  Slytherin

title: Data Warngling II
Data Warngling II
text:
|> works everywhere

R now provides a simple native forward pipe syntax |>. The simple form of the forward pipe inserts the left-hand side as the first argument in the right-hand side call.


factor(c("owl", "fox", "owl")) |> summary()

fox owl 
  1   2

title: Data Warngling II
text:
wizards <- data.frame(
  name = c("Harry", "Bellatrix", "Hermione", "Draco"),
  house = c("Gryffindor", "Slytherin", "Gryffindor",  "Slytherin"),
  height = c(1.78, 1.57, 1.65, 1.75),
  spells = c(60, 75, 70, 55)
)

Using base R data frame subsetting, create from wizards ‚Ä¶

The average height of characters from Gryffindor across each house.


You could set up two pipelines with different filters. But there‚Äôs a better way.

title: Data Warngling II
text:
group_by()
Flag the rows of a dataframe as belong to a group defined by a factor. For use in downstream operations.


wizards |>
    group_by(house)



# A tibble: 4 √ó 4
# Groups:   house [2]
  name      house      height spells
  <chr>     <chr>       <dbl>  <dbl>
1 Harry     Gryffindor   1.78     60
2 Bellatrix Slytherin    1.57     75
3 Hermione  Gryffindor   1.65     70
4 Draco     Slytherin    1.75     55

title: Data Warngling II
Data Warngling II
Data Warngling II
text:
Shortcut: .by
Most "dplyr" functions have a .by argument to apply the function to the groups of another variable.

Not stateful
Good for single line operations



wizards |> 
    summarize(mean(height), .by = house)



       house mean(height)
1 Gryffindor        1.715
2  Slytherin        1.660

title: Geospatial Data
text:
Geographic Data
A collection of ‚Äúobjects‚Äù on which we have information about their geographic location (and possibly other variables or attributes)

Examples of ‚Äúobjects‚Äù on Campus:



Bike racks
Trees
Green areas
Buildings
Swimming pools



Loop stations
Bus stops
Fire hydrants
Bathrooms
ETC

title: Geospatial Data
text: Example: Bike Racks on Campus

title: Geospatial Data
text:
A single unit of geographic data includes:

Location (where): given by a set of coordinates.
Attributes (what): data that describe the location

year of installation
material(s)
capacity (# bikes)
maintenance

title: Geospatial Data
text: Objects (e.g., bike racks) visualized in some kind of map.

title: Geospatial Data
text: How do we know that those coordinates reference that specific location?

title: Geospatial Data
text:
Coordinate Reference System (CRS)




A Coordinate Reference System, or CRS, is a system for associating coordinates with a specific, unambiguous location on the surface of the Earth.

title: Geospatial Data
text:
Two Types of CRSs




Geographic CRS

Angular Units = Degrees

Projected CRS

Cartesian Units = Feet or Meters

title: Geospatial Data
text:
Coordinate Reference Systems (CRS)
There are many CRS, not just one!
Why? Because our understanding of and ability to measure the shape of the earth has changed over time.

title: Geospatial Data
text:
Geographic Coordinate Systems (GCS)
Widely used! Expressed as latitude & longitude


WGS84 (EPSG: 4326)

Based on satellites, used by cell phones, GPS
Best overall fit for most places on earth

NAD83 (EPSG: 4269)

Based on satellites and survey data
Best fit for USA
Used by many federal data products, like Census data

title: Geospatial Data
text:
Projected Coordinate Systems (PCS)



Map Projections transform geographic coordinates (lat/lon) to 2D coordinates (X/Y)
All map projections introduce distortion in area, shape, distance or direction.
Specific map projections minimize distortion in one or more properties
You need to know the coordinate reference system of your input data
You need to select the CRS that is most suitable for your data and application.

title: Geospatial Data
text: Projected Coordinate Systems (PCS)

title: Geospatial Data
text:
In short ‚Ä¶








The Earth is not Flat!

But computer screens, paper maps and most of the math underlying spatial analysis methods assume it is!
We use map projections to transform geographic coordinates from a 3D model of the earth to a 2D plane.
This makes location data much more usable BUT
It introduces distortion.
You need to understand how this distortion impacts your maps and spatial analysis!

text:
Which representation is better A or B?

title: Geospatial Data
text:
Mapping the World in 2 styles
There are two fundamental spatial data models:

title: Geospatial Data
text: Vector Data Geometries

title: Geospatial Data
text: Vector Data Geometris and Attributes

title: Geospatial Data
text:
Vector Data with Attributes
Each row represents one geospatial feature
Attributes describe the features (fields or columns)
Each feature has an associated geometry or geometry collection
A group of features is called a layer

title: Geospatial Data
text: Raster Data

title: Geospatial Data
text:
Raster Data (regular grids)
A location is represented by a grid cell
Cells have regular size, e.g.¬†30x30m
Grid has dimension - fixed number of rows and columns
Each cell has a value that represents the attribute of interest, e.g.¬†elevation

title: Geospatial Data
text:
Vector Data -vs- Raster Data


Vector data are better for discretely bounded data, e.g.¬†bike racks, rivers, political boundaries, etc.


Raster data are better for continuous data, e.g.¬†temperature, elevation, rainfall, etc.

title: Geospatial Data
text:
Some Common File Formats

GeoJSON, JSON
KML (keyhole markup language)
GeoPackage

netCDF
DEM

title: Strings III
text:
Look Arounds
Regex lookarounds are zero-width assertions that match a pattern based on the surrounding text without including the surrounding text in the final match.





Example
description
nickname




a(?=c)
‚Äúa‚Äù followed by ‚Äúc‚Äù
Positive lookahead

title: Explanatory Data Analysis
text:
Exploratory Data Analysis


Features

consumer: the analyst
goals:

get to know the data
uncover structure for further analysis

prioritize quick and accurate interpretation


Common Questions

What is the unit of observation?
What are the variables, their types, and levels?
How is missingness encoded?
What is the distribution of variables?
Are there any interesting outliers?

title: Explanatory Data Analysis
text:
Explanatory Data Analysis


Features

consumer: the stakeholder
goal: tell a specific story
customized
polished aesthetic


Common Questions

Who is my audience?
What is the main story?
What is/are the main analytical task(s)?
Can my plot be clearly read?
Is it polished and customized for audience?

title: Explanatory Data Analysis
text:
Facilitating Comparison

How does this compare to that?
How does this compare to what‚Äôs typical?
How big is this variability relative to that variability?

title: Strings I
text:
Some Special Characters

" normally starts or ends a string. \" is the double-quote character.
t normally is the lowercase Latin t. \t is a tab space.
n normally is the lowercase Latin n.¬†\n is a new line.
U0001F600 normal is just that. \U0001F600 is üòÄ.

title: Strings I
text:
Regular Expressions (regex)
A sequence of characters expressing a string or pattern to be searched for within a longer piece of text.

Regex is not:

a programming language
a markup syntax
a UNIX utility

title: Strings I
text:
Regex
Simply put, regex is
a text string (i.e.¬†set of characters) that defines

a certain amount of text




That ‚Äúcertain amount of text‚Äù is called a pattern.




Regex, at its core, has to do with matching patterns of text.

title: Strings I
text:
2 main types of characters



1) Literal Characters
A literal character is a character that matches itself.




2) Metacharacters
A metacharacter is a character that does NOT match itself.

title: Strings I
text:
Literal Characters

vehicles

[1] "car"      "bike"     "train"    "boat"     "airplane"





Match the letter ‚Äúa‚Äù.

[3] ‚îÇ tr<a>in

Wildcard .

str_view(fives, pattern = "5.")

title: Strings I
text:

any character followed by zero: ‚Äú.0‚Äù

title: Strings I
text:
Escape metacharacter \
But what if the string has an actual period?

fives

[1] "5.00"  "5100"  "5 00"  "5-00"  "$5.55"





How do we match "5." but not "51" (or any other character)?



str_view(fives, pattern = "5\\.")



[1] ‚îÇ <5.>00
[5] ‚îÇ $<5.>55




The first \ escapes it for the string, the second \ escapes it for the regex.

title: Strings I
text:
Character Ranges
A character set is a set of characters defined (grouped) within brackets [  ]

[0123456789]
[abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz]
[ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ]

title: Strings I
text:
Character Ranges
A character set is a set of characters defined (grouped) within brackets [  ]

[0123456789] \(\ \rightarrow \ \) [0-9]
[abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz] \(\ \rightarrow \ \) [a-z]
[ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ] \(\ \rightarrow \ \) [A-Z]


[012...789abc...xyz] \(\ \rightarrow \ \) [0-9a-z]
[012...789ABC...XYZ] \(\ \rightarrow \ \) [0-9A-Z]
[abc...xyzABC...XYZ] \(\ \rightarrow \ \) [a-zA-Z]
[abcdefg34567UVWXYZ] \(\ \rightarrow \ \) [a-g3-7U-Z]

title: Strings I
Strings I
text:
POSIX Classes
A POSIX class is a special set designed as a standardized set to ensure consistency across different regex tools.


POSIX classes are used inside a bracket expression [ ] and are themselves enclosed in [: and :] delimiters.


For example [[:digit:]] which is equivalent to [0-9]

title: Strings I
text:
POSIX Classes

[[:digit:]] analog of [0-9]
[[:alpha:]] analog of [A-Za-z]
[[:alnum:]] analog of [A-Za-z0-9a]
[[:lower:]] analog of [a-z]
[[:upper:]] analog of [A-Z]
[[:space:]] for whitespace characters
[[:punct:]] for punctuation characters
[[:xdigit:]] for hexadecimal digits
[[:blank:]] for space and tab characters

title: Strings I
Strings I
text:
Abbreviated Classes

\s (in R: \\s) : any spaces

equivalent to [[:space:]]

\d (in R: \\d) : digits

equivalent to [[:digit]]

\w (in R: \\w) : ‚Äúword‚Äù character: lower & upper case letters, digits, _

equivalent to [A-Za-z0-9_]

\b (in R: \\b) : word boundaries


There are also negation classes: \S, \D, \W, and \B (in R: \\S, \\D, \\W, \\B)

text:
While you‚Äôre waiting
Imagine you collect University ID number and major from 5 friends:

uid <- c("3850278", "5869204", "4728112", "3829651", "3859278")
maj <- c("statistics", "economics", "statistics", "data", "economics")


Conceptually, in what ways is the data in these two vectors similar? In what ways is it different?
Imagine instead you asked 100 friends. For each vector, can you think of a more efficient way for the computer to store that data?

title: Factors and Data Frames
text:
While you‚Äôre waiting
Imagine you collect University ID number and major from 5 friends:

maj <- c("STAT", "ECON", "STAT", "DATA", "ECON")

Imagine instead you asked 100 friends. For each vector, can you think of a more efficient way for the computer to store that data?

title: Factors and Data Frames
text:
Factors
A data structure for storing categorical data.

Stores the values in an integer vector and adds a levels attribute to map integers to character strings. Created with factor().



maj <- factor(x = c("STAT", "ECON", "STAT", "DATA", "ECON"))
maj



[1] STAT ECON STAT DATA ECON
Levels: DATA ECON STAT

title: Factors and Data Frames
text:
as.integer(maj)

[1] 3 2 3 1 2




c(maj, 2L)

[1] 3 2 3 1 2 2

title: Factors and Data Frames
text:
Attributes
Objects built on top of simpler data structures can have attributes. A factor‚Äôs attributes include its class and levels.


class(maj)



[1] "factor"







levels(maj)



[1] "DATA" "ECON" "STAT"

title: Factors and Data Frames
text:
Setting Levels
Quickly change all of the values with a particular level.


levels(maj) <- c("DATA", "ECON", "STATISTICS")
maj



[1] STATISTICS ECON       STATISTICS DATA       ECON      
Levels: DATA ECON STATISTICS




Add a level even if it‚Äôs not observed.



levels(maj) <- c("DATA", "ECON", "STATISTICS", "BIO")
maj



[1] STATISTICS ECON       STATISTICS DATA       ECON      
Levels: DATA ECON STATISTICS BIO

title: Factors and Data Frames
text:
Taking advantage of class
Certain functions behaved differently depending on the class of the object that is passed to it.


class(1:4)



[1] "integer"





summary(1:4)



   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
   1.00    1.75    2.50    2.50    3.25    4.00 





class(maj)



[1] "factor"





summary(maj)



      DATA       ECON STATISTICS        BIO 
         1          2          2          0

title: Factors and Data Frames
text:
Ordering levels
You can create a factor with ordered levels by adding ordered = TRUE.


maj_or <- factor(x = c("STAT", "ECON", "STAT", "DATA", "ECON"),
                 levels = c("STAT", "ECON", "DATA", "BIO"),
                 ordered = TRUE)
maj_or



[1] STAT ECON STAT DATA ECON
Levels: STAT < ECON < DATA < BIO





sort(maj_or)



[1] STAT STAT ECON ECON DATA
Levels: STAT < ECON < DATA < BIO

title: Factors and Data Frames
text:
barplot(summary(maj_or))












barplot(summary(maj))

title: Factors and Data Frames
text:
Factors and Matrices
Both are augmented versions of atomic vectors that are given classes to allow for special behavior.


mat <- matrix(1:4, ncol = 2)
class(mat)

text:
Data Frame
A data frame is a named list of vectors of the same length. Created with data.frame().


star_wars <- data.frame(
    name = c("Anakin", "Padme", "Luke", "Leia"),
    gender = c("male", "female", "male", "female"),
    height = c(1.88, 1.65, 1.72, 1.50),
    weight = c(84, 45, 77, 49)
)
star_wars

1 Anakin   male   1.88     84
2  Padme female   1.65     45
3   Luke   male   1.72     77
4   Leia female   1.50     49

Leland Wilkinson (1999)



A grammar to describes all statistical graphics.
Underlies most modern data visualization software.

An aesthetic mapping links a variable in the data to a visual attribute.

A plot can be decomposed into three primary elements:

the data,

title: The Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot() syntax

ggplot() builds a plot layer by layer, each one added on top of one another with + (not |>).

ggplot() creates canvas
aes() creates mappings, called inside ggplot() or a geom()
geom_() puts down marks using declared geometry




Usually you specify the data in ggplot()
the data must be a dataframe or tibble

title: The Grammar of Graphics
text:
Layer by layer

penguins |>
  ggplot(aes(x = bill_length_mm,
             y = flipper_length_mm,
             color = species)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_gray(base_size = 18)

title: The Grammar of Graphics
text:
Main inquiries when using "ggplot2"
Always ask yourself:

What is the data set of interest?
What variables (columns) will be used to make the plot?
What graphic objects or geoms will be used to display the data?
What visual attributes will be used to represent the data values?

x, y
color, fill
shape
etc

title: Functions
text:
Ex. colSums()


mat <- matrix(1:4, nrow = 2)
mat



     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    1    3
[2,]    2    4





colSums(mat)



[1] 3 7




How could I compute this without colSums()?

c(sum(mat[, 1]), sum(mat[, 2]))



[1] 3 7

title: Functions
text:
I could generalize with a for-loop

colsum_vec <- rep(0, ncol(mat))

for (coln in 1:ncol(mat)) {
  colsum_vec[coln] <- sum(mat[, coln])
}

colsum_vec



[1] 3 7

title: Functions
text:
Why use colSums() instead?

Make your code more readable
Don‚Äôt Repeat Yourself (DRY)
Focus on the variables, not the constants
Easier to test, update

title: Functions
text:
Building a function


# celsius to fahrenheit
c2f <- function(celsius) {
  (9/5) * celsius + 32
}


Create a new function with function()
Define the function name, arguments, and expression
Creates a new object, c2f() in your environment
Last line will be returned (or use return())

title: Functions
text:
Scoping
Question: What will the following code return?

a <- 10
b <- 20

hey <- function() {
  a <- 1
  b <- 2
  c(a, b)
}

hey()



[1] 1 2

title: Functions
text:
a <- 2

yay <- function() {
  b <- 1
  c(a, b)
}

yay()



[1] 2 1



The environment within the function includes the environment ‚Äúone level up‚Äù
Objects defined in the function environment mask those one level up
Best to encapsulate functions (not make them dependent on objects defined outside their environment / arguments)

title: Lists
text:
Atomic Vectors
By atomic we mean:

All elements of the same type
Cannot contain other vectors

title: Lists
text:
Lists, defined
A list is a non-atomic vector that can contain:

Atomic vectors of different types
Other lists


Created with list()

list(1, "two")

title: Lists
text:
Subsetting with []
[] extracts elements of a vector (atomic or non-atomic) using a subsetting (atomic) vector.

Atomic vectors and matrices return atomic vectors



vec <- 1:4
vec[1:2]



[1] 1 2





mat <- matrix(vec, nrow = 2)
mat



     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    1    3
[2,]    2    4

title: Lists
text:
Subsetting with []
[] extracts elements of a vector (atomic or non-atomic) using a subsetting (atomic) vector.

Atomic vectors and matrices return atomic vectors
Lists returns lists



x <- list(1:3, "a", 4:6)
x[1]



[[1]]
[1] 1 2 3





x[2:3]



[[1]]
[1] "a"

[[2]]

text:

named_x <- list("Ape" = 1:3, "Boy" = "a", "Cat" = 4:6)

section: Yes, it works with logicals too
text:
Yes, it works with logicals too


named_x <- list("Ape" = 1:3, "Boy" = "a", "Cat" = 4:6)
named_x[c(FALSE, TRUE, FALSE)]



$Boy
[1] "a"





But what if you want the actual data structure inside the list?

title: Working with Vectors

Vectors

Central data structure in R
Ordered set of elements

title: Working with Vectors
text:
Atomic*
Special values in an atomic vector.

NA: Not Available / Missing
NULL: Does not exist (nothing)
NaN: Not a Number (e.g.¬†dividing by zero)
Inf: Infinity

title: Working with Vectors
text:
A comment about comments
Comment character: special character to skip evaluation of remaining characters on a line. R (and Python) use #.


# create vector
c("A", "C", "D") # vector created!



[1] "A" "C" "D"




vs.

create vector

text:
Vectorization
Vectorized: Operations and functions that can run on an entire vector at once.

dbl_vec <- c(1, 2.3, 4)

[1] 0.0000000 0.8329091 1.3862944

title: Working with Vectors
text:
Vector Recycling
Vector Recycling: If a function requires a longer vector than provided, it will fill the vector with the existing elements, in order.

c(2, 6, 1)^2

[1]  4 36  1

title: Working with Vectors
text:
Coercion
Implicit Coercion: Automatic change of data types to ensure atomic vectors. Changes follow a hierarchy.
logical < integer < double < character

title: Working with Vectors
text:
Coercion
Explicit Coercion: R provides functions to explicitly coerce from one type to another.

as.logical()
as.integer()
as.double()
as.character()


Depending on what data-type you want to coerce to, these functions may or may not work.



as.double(c(TRUE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE))

title: Strings II
text:
Recap
Last time we learned about:

literal characters
wildcard metacharacter: .
escape metacharacter: \, (in R is \\)
character sets (aka character classes)

e.g.¬†set of lower case vowels: [aeiou]
e.g.¬†set of all digits: [0123456789]
character ranges: [0-9] , [a-z] , [A-Z] , [3-7d-mQ-Y]
POSIX classes: e.g.¬†[[:digit:]], [[:alpha:]], [[:alnum:]]
abbreviated: e.g.¬†\\s, \\d, \\w, \\b

title: Strings II
text:
Character Vectors

teas <- c("taro", "green", "black", "matcha", "jasmine")




vehicles <- c("car", "bike", "train", "boat", "airplane")




fives <- c("5.00", "5100", "5 00", "5-00", "$5.55")

  "LEIA is a 1.50 meters tall Female",

)


str_view(sw, pattern = "[A-Z]")

[1] ‚îÇ <L><E><I><A> is a 1.50 meters tall <F>emale
[2] ‚îÇ <L><U><K><E> is a 1.70 meters tall <M>ale
[3] ‚îÇ <H><A><N> is a 1.80 meters tall <M>ale

title: Strings II
text:
Anchors
You can anchor the regular expression using ^ to match the start or $ to match the end.


Example:

^a: stars with ‚Äúa‚Äù
a$: ends with ‚Äúa‚Äù

title: Strings II
text:
vehicles

[1] "car"      "bike"     "train"    "boat"     "airplane"






# start with vowel
str_view(vehicles, pattern = "^[aeiou]")

[5] ‚îÇ <a>irplane

title: Strings II
Strings II
text:
Anchors

vehicles

[1] "car"      "bike"     "train"    "boat"     "airplane"




# first character
str_view(vehicles, pattern = "^.")

[1] ‚îÇ <c>ar
[2] ‚îÇ <b>ike
[3] ‚îÇ <t>rain
[4] ‚îÇ <b>oat
[5] ‚îÇ <a>irplane





# last character
str_view(vehicles, pattern = ".$")

[1] ‚îÇ ca<r>
[2] ‚îÇ bik<e>
[3] ‚îÇ trai<n>
[4] ‚îÇ boa<t>
[5] ‚îÇ airplan<e>

title: Strings II
text:
Quantifiers



Example
Description
Quantity




"a*"
matches ‚Äúa‚Äù any number of times
[0, \(\infty\))


"a+"
matches at least one ‚Äúa‚Äù
[1, \(\infty\))


"a?"
optional number of ‚Äúa‚Äù
[0, 1]


"a{5}"
5 consecutive a‚Äôs
5


"a{3,6}"
between 3 and 6 a‚Äôs
[3, 6]


"a{3,}"
3 or more a‚Äôs
\(\geq 3\)

title: Strings II
text:
abc <- c("a", "aab", "aaabbc", "bcc")



# any number of "a"
str_extract(abc, pattern = "a*")



[1] "a"   "aa"  "aaa" ""   





# at least one "a"
str_extract(abc, pattern = "a+")



[1] "a"   "aa"  "aaa" NA   





# optional "a"
str_extract(abc, pattern = "a?")



[1] "a" "a" "a" ""

title: Strings II
text:
abc <- c("a", "aab", "aaabbc", "bcc")



# 2 consecutive "a"
str_extract(abc, pattern = "a{2}")



[1] NA   "aa" "aa" NA  





# 1 or 2 "a"
str_extract(abc, pattern = "a{1,2}")



[1] "a"  "aa" "aa" NA  





# 3 or more "a"
str_extract(abc, pattern = "a{3,}")



[1] NA    NA    "aaa" NA   





# at most 3 "a"
str_extract(abc, pattern = "a{0,3}")



[1] "a"   "aa"  "aaa" ""

title: Strings II
text:
Quantifiers (cheat sheet)



Example
Description




"a*"
Any amount (unlim allowed; none required)


"a+"
At least one (unlim allowed; one required)


"a?"
One optional (one allowed; none required)


"a{n}"
n consecutive times


"a{min,max}"
Interval including min and max


"a{min,}"
Min required, no max limit

title: Strings II
text:
Grouping
You can change the scope of different operations by grouping characters with ()


x <- c("hah", "hahaha", "haaa")




str_view(x, pattern = "ha+")



[1] ‚îÇ <ha>h
[2] ‚îÇ <ha><ha><ha>
[3] ‚îÇ <haaa>





str_view(x, pattern = "(ha)+")



[1] ‚îÇ <ha>h
[2] ‚îÇ <hahaha>
[3] ‚îÇ <ha>aa

title: Strings II
text:
Alternation
You can separate different possible patterns with |; reads like ‚Äúor‚Äù

vehicles

[1] "car"      "bike"     "train"    "boat"     "airplane"




str_view(vehicles, "in|ir")



[3] ‚îÇ tra<in>
[5] ‚îÇ a<ir>plane





str_view(vehicles, "ar|an")



[1] ‚îÇ c<ar>
[5] ‚îÇ airpl<an>e





str_view(vehicles, "a(r|n|t)")



[1] ‚îÇ c<ar>
[4] ‚îÇ bo<at>
[5] ‚îÇ airpl<an>e

title: Syllabus
text: This is an in-person class with three lectures each week and one two-hour lab led by a GSI. This class is designed assuming you‚Äôll be in class. If you miss class, you‚Äôll be able to find most materials from class - slides, snippets of code - published on the course wesite.

title: Syllabus
text:
Materials

Computational tools
Each student will need a laptop in order to engage with the computing aspects of this class. Throughout the semester you‚Äôll be installing several different software tools, all of which are free. We will be mainly using the computing and programming environment R (via Positron or RStudio) to analyze data in this class. We will also ask you to use a command line interface to interact with your operating system. You do need your own computer to use R and do the assignments. No need to install these ahead of time; we‚Äôll guide you through how to get set up.
About half of the students in STAT 133 have some coding experience in Python or R and about half do not. For those who come from Data 8 or some previous coding experience in python, the first labs will help you transfer that knowledge over to R. Both languages are excellent platforms for analyzing data, are widely used in data science, and have their individual strengths. R has been developed within the statistics community specifically for data analysis, while python is a general-purpose programming language but has large data analysis capabilities.

title: Syllabus
text:
Course communication

bCourses
We use bCourses to disseminate important announcements for the entire class such as the initial welcome announcement, final exam information etc. Also, this is where you will be submitting one or more components associated to your assignments (e.g.¬†problem sets, projects)


Discussion forum
The official discussion forum for the class will be hosted on Ed. Ed is a forum to ask and answer questions with your fellow students and course staff. It‚Äôs a useful resource for learning from your peers and seeking help from tutors and instructors.
If you have a question about the material or assignments (or anything related to the course), create a new post to ask your question on Ed. If it is about something personal, then mark it as ‚Äúprivate‚Äù, and only course staff will be able to see your post. This is the best way to contact us if you have a personal concern, as it ensures the fastest response. If your question does not include personal information and can be answered by other students, make sure it is public.
In a course this large, the instructors have a difficult time responding to individual emails, so please use the class forum or visit office hours if you wish to contact us.

title: Syllabus
text:
Assignments, Exams, and Grading

Turning-in assignments
You will be turning in your assignments on bCourses. This is also the platform where your assignments will be graded, so you can return there to get feedback on your work. You are welcome to file a regrade request if you notice that we made an error in applying the rubric to your work. Note that regrade requests will need to be submitted by a deadline, which will usually be two days after the grades are released.


Problem Sets
Problem sets are weekly assignments that provide you with essential practice on the ideas and techniques discussed in class. They are generally due each week on Wednesday by 6PM and are graded credit / no credit.


Quarto Publications
Except for a couple of labs (e.g.¬†first and last lab), during discussion you will have the opportunity to publish a variety of demo documents‚Äîusing some flavor of quarto file‚Äîto your QuartoPub account. These demo publications will help you to be ready for the publication of your Projects. They are due each Thursday during discussion (deadline by 6PM) and are graded credit / no credit.


Projects
Projects are biweekly open-ended assignments designed to apply the concepts from the lecture notes in the cause of doing an analysis of real data. This will involve both writing code and communicating your thoughts and findings in English. In addition, you will be publishing your Projects to your QuartoPub account. Time permitting, we‚Äôll be working through some problems from the projects in lab section, but you will be spending time on them outside of class time. Projcets are generally due every other week on Friday by 6PM and are graded credit / no credit.


Quizzes
Paper-and-pencil quizzes reinforce the most important concepts from the lecture and provide you the opportunity to work through misunderstandings of concepts with peers and the instructor. They cover the material from lecture, problem sets, and projects up until the time of the quiz.


Final Exam
The paper-and-pencil final exam will be held in person during finals week. It is a comprehensive exam and covers the material from the lecture, problem sets, and projects.
The time and date is Monday May 11th, 7-10 pm.


Grading
Your final grade in this class is, to the best of our ability, a measure of your understanding of the concepts of computing with data. As such, the lions share of your grade comes from measures of your individual understanding: quizzes and the final.
The best way to prepare for these assessments is to earnestly engage with the problem sets and projects. Their role in the course is practice and they‚Äôll be your single most effective way to learn. We just want to see that you are indeed engaging in practice, so the problem sets and projects are both graded credit / no credit, with full credit given for evidence of earnest engagement.
In order to provide flexibility around emergencies and extenuating circumstances that might arise for you throughout the semester we will drop your lowest 2 problem sets and your lowest quiz grade.
Your final grade will be calculated as follows:

Quarto Publications: 5%
Problem Sets: 10% (drop lowest 2)
Projects: 15%
Quizzes: 40% (drop lowest 1)
Final: 30%

The grades will not be curved (> 90% is some kind of A, 80-90 is some kind of B, etc.), so there is no limit to the number of As and Bs that are earned.
As a matter of course policy, I do not round up when calculating letter grades. For instance: if your overall score is 79.9999%, then the highest letter grade that you can expect is some kind of C, not a B-.

title: Syllabus
text:
Policies

Late Work
Rigorously completing the publications, problem sets and projects is for your own benefit. Since we grade them credit / no credit, no late work is accepted. Note that you can receive full credit for an assignment that is not complete as long as we see evidence of earnest engagment (please don‚Äôt just submit a blank or empty template file).


Collaboration policy
On problem sets and projects, we strongly encourage collaboration between students. One of the best ways to learn is to talk things through with someone else. At the same time, these are your best opportunity to practice and learn, so be cautious not to lean to heavily on the understanding of a peer when working through your assignments.


AI policy
Please be thoughtful when using AI tools for your schoolwork. Doing so on problem sets and projects robs you of a valuable opportunity to learn and undermines your performance on exams. At the same time, they can be helpful in providing feedback on your writing.
At the end of the course‚Äîtime permitting‚Äîwe‚Äôll bring in AI tools for coding and learn how to use them. They‚Äôre very powerful, but you need firm mental models of the way code works before you‚Äôre able to use them well. For that reason, we suggest you refrain from using them until they‚Äôre introduced in class.


Accomodations for students with disabilities
STAT 133 is a course that is designed to allow all students to succeed. If you have letters of accommodation from the Disabled Students‚Äô Program, please share them with your instructor as soon as possible, and we will work out the necessary arrangements.


Staying healthy
Maintaining your health and that of the Berkeley community is of primary importance, so if you are feeling ill or have been exposed to illness, whether it‚Äôs COVID-19 or something else, please do not come to class. You‚Äôre encouraged to reach out to fellow students to discuss the class materials or stop by group tutoring or office hours to chat with a tutor or the instructor.

title: Ed-Discussion Netiquette
text:
Unfortunately, we just don‚Äôt have enough human resources to have a dedicated Ed-Discussion moderator. We will do our best to monitor this tool once per day from Monday to Friday. Please note that we may not be able to monitor Ed during the evening nor weekend. That‚Äôs why we strongly encourage student participation on Ed-Discussion rather than answering right away (i.e.¬†we want other students step up and answer questions).
In the past, some students have decided to use external discussion forums. When used responsibly and appropriately, we think that‚Äôs a great idea. But we have never endorsed their use, nor we have monitored, moderated or managed them, and we won‚Äôt do that this time.
In order to make Ed-Discussion a better resource for everyone, we‚Äôve outlined some guidelines for you to follow when posting on this tool. Questions which follow these guidelines tend to have a higher chance of being answered!

Please adhere to the same standards of behavior online that you follow in real life.
We want to make sure that you are helping each other out, and having instructors give away the answers isn‚Äôt the most beneficial for your education either.

title: Ed-Discussion Netiquette
text:
Unfortunately, we just don‚Äôt have enough human resources to have a dedicated Ed-Discussion moderator. We will do our best to monitor this tool once per day from Monday to Friday. Please note that we may not be able to monitor Ed during the evening nor weekend. That‚Äôs why we strongly encourage student participation on Ed-Discussion rather than answering right away (i.e.¬†we want other students step up and answer questions).
In the past, some students have decided to use external discussion forums. When used responsibly and appropriately, we think that‚Äôs a great idea. But we have never endorsed their use, nor we have monitored, moderated or managed them, and we won‚Äôt do that this time.
In order to make Ed-Discussion a better resource for everyone, we‚Äôve outlined some guidelines for you to follow when posting on this tool. Questions which follow these guidelines tend to have a higher chance of being answered!

Please adhere to the same standards of behavior online that you follow in real life.
We want to make sure that you are helping each other out, and having instructors give away the answers isn‚Äôt the most beneficial for your education either.

title: Ed-Discussion Netiquette
section: Keep in mind common rules of netiquette
text:
Keep in mind common rules of netiquette

Don‚Äôt post irrelevant links, comments, thoughts or pictures.
Don‚Äôt type in ALL CAPS! If you do it will look like you are screaming.
Don‚Äôt write anything that sounds angry or sarcastic even as a joke, because without hearing your tone of voice, your peers might not realize you‚Äôre joking.
Always remember to say ‚Äúplease‚Äù and ‚Äúthank you‚Äù when soliciting help from your classmates.
Respect the opinion of your classmates. If you feel the need to disagree, do so respectfully and acknowledge the valid points in your classmate‚Äôs argument.
Refrain from personal abuse. Don‚Äôt badmouth others or call them offensive words. You may express robust disagreement with what someone says, but don‚Äôt call them names.
Be forgiving. If your classmate makes a mistake, don‚Äôt badger him or her for it. Just let it go.
If you reply to a question from a classmate, make sure your answer is accurate.
Be brief. If you write a long dissertation in response to a simple question, it‚Äôs unlikely that anyone will spend the time to read through it all.
Remember that your public posts are not anonymous. They can be read by your classmates.
Don‚Äôt expect other people to do your homework for you. If you‚Äôre looking for technical help, for example, don‚Äôt ask questions you could easily answer yourself by reading the manual or help documentation provided with the software tools used in this course.

title: Ed-Discussion Netiquette
section: Ask Lab and HW questions only in the designated Lab and HW posts
text:
Ask Lab and HW questions only in the designated Lab and HW posts
We‚Äôve created individual posts for each type of assignment. Please ask questions, discuss problems, or help out in those posts only. Before asking a question, read through (or search) the whole thread to see if your question has been answered. Likewise, stay on topic.

title: Ed-Discussion Netiquette
section: Do NOT post answers in discussion forums
text:
Do NOT post answers in discussion forums
Please don‚Äôt give away the answer on any discussion forum. You can explain things in a way that still lets other students figure out the essence of the problem on their own, but don‚Äôt spoil the problem. For example, don‚Äôt point to a useful stackoverflow or YouTube link that works out essentially what the problem is asking about.
That is not cool.
Post such spoilers after the HW is due. That is totally fine. If you are not sure, post privately to instructors and then we‚Äôll let you know.

title: Ed-Discussion Netiquette
text:
Ask questions about assignments only
If you have questions, comments, or other concerns that are not related to assignments, please email your GSI or the instructor. We want to keep the focus of bCourses tools for assignments in Stat 133.

title: Ed-Discussion Netiquette
text:
Try to make posts public
While not violating the preceding rules, try to make your questions public, because others might have the same question and we don‚Äôt need to answer them multiple times.

title: Ed-Discussion Netiquette
text:
3 minute-test
If you think your questions may take more than 3 or 5 minutes to answer, please come to office hours, or try to schedule a zoom meeting with the teaching staff.

title: Ed-Discussion Netiquette
text:
We are not pre-grading
Please do not post questions of the form:

‚ÄúIs this the correct solution to HW X problem Y?‚Äù
‚ÄúWould this receive full credit on HW X problem Y?‚Äù
‚ÄúIs this the right level of detail for HW X problem Y?‚Äù

Please do not ask instructors to check your homework in advance. We simply cannot check every student‚Äôs homework.
Feel free to ask questions of clarification about a certain HW problem, or ask questions about the course content to achieve a deeper understanding, but at a certain point, you must apply your knowledge, give it your best shot, and submit your answers with confidence.

title: Ed-Discussion Netiquette
section: Post a screenshot of any resource referenced
text:
Post a screenshot of any resource referenced
Your question should be self-contained. The GSIs (and other responders) should not have to scan through PDFs or scripts to even figure out what the question is. Ask yourself: am I referring to some lecture /HW solution/discussion solution/etc?
If the answer is yes, post a screenshot of the relevant part. This can include your handwritten notes from the relevant lecture.

title: Ed-Discussion Netiquette
text:
Post all your work
Don‚Äôt post one line saying:

‚ÄúAt step n, I get XYZ, and I‚Äôm now confused.‚Äù
This forces the GSIs to guess:
What happened in steps 1, 2, ‚Ä¶, n - 1?

Most likely, the GSIs will guess wrong, and we run into a mess of followup questions trying to figure out what steps 1, 2, ‚Ä¶, n - 1 were.
Instead, post:

Starting out, we have: ‚Ä¶.
Then, I do ‚Ä¶, and I get ‚Ä¶
Next, I do ‚Ä¶, and I get ‚Ä¶
Next, I do ‚Ä¶, and I get ‚Ä¶
Now, I get $&%&#(, and this makes no sense.
Then, the GSI can respond:
The mistake is at step 3, you‚Äôre not allowed to apply ABC to XYZ because ‚Ä¶

In summary, when you do ask for help, include details of what attempts you‚Äôve made to solve the problem. It will save time and also show people that you are making an effort to help yourself.

We reserve the right to delete any posts
We reserve the right to delete, move, or edit any posts, and even to make Ed-Discussion inactive, at any time, without previous notice.
Discussion resources can be a great tools if used appropriately, respectfully, and wisely. Take advantage of Ed, and make the most out of it.

title: Communication via Email
text:
Email: gastonsanchez@berkeley.edu
You should limit your emails to serious problems that cannot be addressed during office hours. The vast majority of questions can be answered during OH. Email should not be used for information that is readily available in course materials (syllabus, discussion forum, announcements, etc.) or from fellow students.
I do not explain course material over email and will not respond to emails with such requests. Please use office hours, or discussion section, (or schedule another time to meet with the teaching staff if you have irreconcilable conflicts with the office hours).

title: Communication via Email
text:
Reading and responding email
For general emails, I will reply to general questions or concerns within 2 to 3 business days, Monday through Friday, during regular academic hours (9:00AM-5:00PM).
Please note that I do not read email between 5pm and 9am, or during the weekends. Likewise, I do not respond to emails on the weekend.
ex. If you send an email at 6pm on Friday night, you can expect that I will read it around 9am on Monday morning, and should likely receive a response by around 9am on Tuesday morning.
If, for any reason, I haven‚Äôt responded to your email after four business days, please email me again. I am human, and there are times when student emails fall through the cracks inadvertently.
I prefer to have conversations in person rather than via email, thus allowing us to get to know each other better and fostering a more collegial learning atmosphere.

title: Communication via Email
text:
Communicate in a professional manner
If you believe your situation warrants an email, please feel free to send me a professional email. E-mail communication should be courteous and respectful in manner and tone. Please do not send e-mails that are curt or demanding.
Here‚Äôs a short example of an unprofessional email. Let‚Äôs assume you missed an exam, for whatever reason. Do not write and say: ‚ÄúI missed an exam. When can I make it up?‚Äù Instead, explain why you have extenuating circumstances, and ask the teaching staff if they will allow you to make up the exam. Most likely you won‚Äôt be able to make it up, but at least you are asking in a professional way.
If you are unsure of how to write an email to me or any other professor, please consult this amusing blog post that gives you a useful template:
https://medium.com/@lportwoodstacer/how-to-email-your-professor-without-being-annoying-af-cf64ae0e4087

title: Communication via Email
text:
Subject line
If you wish for your email to make it into my inbox, do not leave the subject line blank. Instead, make sure the subject of your email contains the code course and a brief explanation of the nature of the email. For example: ‚ÄúStat 133-Question about Homework‚Äù or ‚ÄúStat 133-Request for Meeting‚Äù.

title: Communication via Email
text:
Avoid these subjects

Avoid emailing me to explain why you missed or will miss class. I usually don‚Äôt need to know. If you think this is affecting your performance, then schedule a meeting with me.
Do not email me to let me know you made a mistake in your submitted assignment. Please refer to the HW policies (see syllabus).
Do not email me to ask for extra credit. Here‚Äôs why: https://marktomforde.com/academic/undergraduates/NoExtraCredit.html
Above all, do not email me to engage in grade grubbing. Here‚Äôs why: https://marktomforde.com/academic/undergraduates/GradeGrubbing.html

title: Communication via Email
text:
Scheduling a meeting
If you wish to schedule a meeting with me, your message should include at least two times when you would like to meet and a brief (one-two sentence) description of the reason for the meeting.

title: Communication via Email
text:
Emails regarding letters of recommendation
Before you ask me to write you a letter of recommendation, please take a look at the following document: https://github.com/gastonstat/letter-of-rec

title: Some Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Will STAT 133 be offered in hybrid mode (both in-person and remotely, simultaneously)?  No, STAT 133 will not be offered in hybrid mode. Instead, all classes and sections are to be delivered in-person. If you have time conflicts with lecture and/or section, please don‚Äôt take STAT 133 this semester.

Will there be live webcast or recordings of lectures?  No.¬†The class is designed assuming that you‚Äôll be present in both lecture and discussion.

What can I do if I have to miss class?  Missing a class should be a truly exceptional occurrence‚Äîreserved for emergencies or significant personal illness‚Äîrather than a recurring habit. On a side note, here‚Äôs one fun fact from the students‚Äô course evaluations. The most common answer provided by the students when asked ‚ÄúWhat advice would you give to another student who is considering taking this course?‚Äù is: ‚ÄúGo to all the lectures and labs and start working on assignments early.‚Äù
I understand that your lives are incredibly full and that you are often navigating a heavy load of assignments, exams, job interviews, and various personal and extracurricular commitments. While it can be tempting to deprioritize this class when other deadlines feel more urgent, please remember that STAT 133 is a cumulative course where each session builds directly upon the previous one. Losing focus, even temporarily, can create significant gaps in your understanding that are difficult to bridge later in the semester.
Your presence not only keeps you in sync with our cumulative material but also enriches the experience for your peers, as your unique questions and insights often spark the most meaningful ‚Äúlightbulb moments‚Äù for everyone in the room. My goal is for you to not only succeed but to master these analytical tools for your future careers. To achieve this, I ask that you treat our class time and coursework as a non-negotiable priority in your schedule. If you find yourself consistently overwhelmed, please reach out to us early so we can discuss strategies for managing the workload effectively. Last but not least, please don‚Äôt take STAT 133 lightly. If you feel that you cannot commit to attending all lectures and labs, please consider dropping the course and enrolling in a future semester when you can give it your full attention.

I am a Concurrent Enrollment student. What are my chances of enrolling in the class?  Concurrent Enrollment students will only be allowed to enroll if (a) there is space in the course and all UC Berkeley students who want to take the course have had a chance to enroll, meaning there should be no waitlist, and (b) we have determined that you have remained engaged with all the learning activities since the beginning of instruction. This includes, but is not limited to: attending lectures and labs, participating in discussions, completing assignments on time, and overall demonstrating a commitment to learning the material.
Keep in mind that the approval process for concurrent enrollment students takes place between the 2nd and 3rd week of instruction, and it is a somewhat slow 2-step process, which takes some days, and it involves not only my intervention but also the participation of one of the advisors in the Dept. of Statistics.

I am a grad student officially enrolled. Do you have a grading structure for grad students?  This semester we don‚Äôt have a special grading structure for graduate students. All students will be evaluated with the same criteria. See the course syllabus for more information about the grading structure.

What if I join the class late?  If you join the class within the first two weeks, read the syllabus and lecture notes, take a look at bCourses to get a sense of any assignments that may have already passed, and visit office hours to check that you‚Äôre up to date with things. Please keep in mind that we will not be providing late or make-up submissions for any missed assignments.
I do not recommend joining the class after two weeks into the semester, so you will have to wait to a subsequent semester to take STAT 133.

Are time conflicts allowed?  STAT 133 does not allow students to enroll with time conflicts.

I would like to switch lab sections with other student. Is this possible?  This is not possible. You should attend the lab section you are officially enrolled in. If you have a time conflict with your lab section, please drop the course and enroll in a different section that fits your schedule or wait until a future semester to take STAT 133.

Is this course a good fit if I don‚Äôt have any programming experience?  Quick answer: yes. Because Stat 133 has no prerequisites, we actually expect that many of you come without any coding experience. It is nice to have some programming experience under your belt, which makes the learning curve less steep. Having said that, if this is your first time coding, you should expect to spend a great amount of time doing work outside class (and also deal with the inevitable frustration that comes when learning any language).

What if I don‚Äôt have any data analysis experience?  No problem. Because STAT 133 has no prerequisites, we actually expect that most of you come without any data analysis experience. In this course you will be working with a variety of fairly simple real data sets, as well as with simulated data.

What if I‚Äôve already taken several programming courses?  You may find some parts of this course somewhat slow (and boring?) in terms of basics concepts such as data types, data structures, conditionals, loops, and functions. Unless STAT 133 is a required course for your major/minor (or you are eager to learn about R), please consider taking more advanced courses if what you are interested in is algorithms, computational statistics, databases, machine learning and statistical learning.

Is this course a good fit if I don‚Äôt intend to major in Statistics?  STAT 133 is one of the core courses of the Statistics Major. The way I‚Äôve been teaching this course is having Statistics majors as my target audience. However, much of the content should be helpful for any student who has to analyze data, or for those majors with some sort of data-analysis concentration.

Is this course a good fit to become a data scientist?  Becoming a data scientist is not a (one-semester) sprint. It is a (years-long) marathon. Like any other profession, it takes many years of learning, practice, practice, practice, and then some practice, to become a proficient data scientist/analyst. This course can be very useful, and we are confident it will help you to build a good foundation in your DS career.

What if I don‚Äôt want to be a data scientist?  That‚Äôs perfect too. You don‚Äôt need to be a data scientist aspirant to take this course. Whether your plans are to become a consultant, life scientist, social scientist, journalist, or get some analytic skills, this course should be a good choice.

Why is R (and not python) the main computational tool used in Stat 133?  Historically, STAT 133 has always been taught with R, and this semester is no exception. Personally, I believe that both R and python are great tools, and it is a good idea that you learn both of them (especially if you are interested in Data Science, analytics, etc). STAT 133 gives you the opportunity to learn a fair amount of R. Quoting Hadley Wickham:

‚ÄúGenerally, there are a lot of people who talk about R versus Python like it‚Äôs a war that either R or Python is going to win. I think that is not helpful because it is not actually a battle. These things exist independently and are both awesome in different ways‚Äù.

On a side note, Ross Ihaka, one of the creators of R, obtained his PhD at UC Berkeley (in the Dept. of Statistics), so it is no coincidence that we are heavily influenced by R.

Are we going to learn about machine learning methods?  The Statistics department offers a dedicated course on this topic: STAT 154: Modern Statistical Prediction and Machine Learning. There is also CS 189: Introduction to Machine Learning offered through Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences (EECS). Similarly, DATA 100: Principles and Techniques of Data Science covers several machine learning concepts.

Are we going to learn about databases?  If you are interested in Databases you should consider CS 186: Introduction to Database Systems offered through Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences (EECS).

Are we going to learn about linear models?  The Statistics department offers a dedicated course on this topic: STAT 151A: Linear Modeling, Theory and Applications.

Are we going to learn about introductory statistics and/or probability?  The Statistics department offers two core courses on these topics: STAT 134: Concepts of Probability, and STAT 135: Concepts of Statistics.

Can we work in groups?  Yes, absolutely. We strongly encourage you to not work alone. Well, let me rephrase that. You should try to first work on your own (trial and error). Take notes of the things you don‚Äôt understand. Then get with other people and discuss ideas, share tips (but not the entire solution).

What if I don‚Äôt agree with all the course policies?  If there is one or more policies you don‚Äôt agree with, then please reconsider your enrollment in the course. I am assuming that all students completely agree with the course policies described in the Syllabus.

Can I ask you to write me a Letter of Recommendation (LoR)?  Please take a look at this document before asking me to write you a letter of recommendation: https://github.com/gastonstat/letter-of-rec.

I invited you to join my network in LinkedIn. Why haven‚Äôt you accepted my invitation?  First: Don‚Äôt take it personal. It‚Äôs not you, it‚Äôs me. Second: if you really want that I become part of your network, why don‚Äôt you talk to me in person? We can meet in Office Hours, or you can also schedule a meeting at a different time. Let me know you better than just as a distant contact in a social media networking site.

You can assign into a subsetted vector to change its contents in place.

z <- c(latte = 2, boba = 4, matcha = 6)

z

names(z) <- c("A", "B", "C")

title: Extending Vectors
text:
Matrix
A two-dimensional data structure for atomic data. Created with matrix().

mat1 <- matrix(data = c(1, 2, 3, 4), nrow = 2)
mat1



     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    1    3
[2,]    2    4




typeof(mat1)



[1] "double"




Note: defaults to fill the matrix by columns (byrow = FALSE)

title: Extending Vectors
text:
Matrices as Vectors

vec <- 1:4
dim(vec) <- c(2, 2)
vec



     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    1    3
[2,]    2    4



Matrices are simply vectors with dimensions dim(). All vector behavior still applies.

title: Introduction

title: Introduction
text:
Computing with data involves dealing with multiple files:

some files will be inputs
some files will be outputs
some files will be data files
some files will be image files
some files will be script files (code)
some files will be reports
some files will play auxiliary roles


It‚Äôs important to have a good organization of files

title: Introduction
text:
An Analogy


Messy file system üò¢


Neat file system üòç

title: Introduction
text:
Main Unix Concepts

The filesystem is a hierarchy (of folders & files)
Files organized in a tree structure (‚Äúinverted tree‚Äù)

title: Introduction
text:
Main Unix Concepts

Everything is a File (including directories)
Folder = Directory
No concept of ‚Äúdisk‚Äù
At any given time we are inside a directory
The current directory is the working directory
From that directory we can move up or down

title: Introduction
text:
Special Directories
Root directory: the top-level folder in a computer‚Äôs file system, acting as the main starting point from which all other directories and files branch out, similar to the trunk of a tree


Home directory: a user‚Äôs personal folder in a multi-user operating system that holds their private files, settings, and data, acting as their default workspace upon login.


Working directory: the specific folder in a computer‚Äôs file system where a user is currently working or where a process is executing commands.

title: Introduction
text: The Very Basics

title: Introduction
text:
File Paths
Each file and directory has a unique name in the filesystem called a path.



File paths can be specified in 2 ways:

Absolute Paths: always from the root directory.
Relative Paths: location relative to a working directory.

title: Introduction
text:
Special Symbols





Symbol
Meaning




/
root directory (1st slash)


A/B
A contains B (intermediate slash)


~
home directory (i.e.¬†/home/user/)


.
current directory


..
parent directory

title: Introduction
text:
Advantages of Relative Paths
Portability: Your code works anywhere (your machine, a colleague‚Äôs, a web server) without changing paths, as long as the file structure within the project remains consistent.



Flexibility: You can restructure folders within your project.




Self-Contained Projects: Keeps everything needed for the project bundled together.




Simpler References: Shorter paths are quicker to type and less prone to errors than long absolute paths.

    records.html

title: Joins and Pivots

tbl1 <- tibble(
  name = c("Harry", "Hermione", "Ron"),
  gpa = c(3.8, 4.0, 3.0),
  coffee = c("yes", "no", "yes")
)

  name = c("Harry", "Bellatrix", "Hermione", "Draco"),
  spells = c(60, 75, 70, 55),
  lunch = c("pizza", "tacos", "burrito", "pad thai")
)

title: Joins and Pivots
text:
Joins
A join is an operation that combines two data frames by linking the rows by their unique identifier called a key.



This can be done in six ways:

Left join
Right join
Full join
Inner join
Semi join
Anti join

title: Joins and Pivots
text:
Left Join
All rows from x, and all columns from x and y. Rows in x with no match in y will have NA values in the new columns.

title: Joins and Pivots
text:
About Pivots
Pivoting is a method to reshape a data frame to become either wider or longer. Requires that you specify the names and values involved in any transformation. Implemented in "tidyr".

library(tidyverse) # contains "tidyr"





pivot_longer(data, cols, names_to, values_to)




pivot_wider(data, names_from, values_from)

title: Importing Tables
text:
scan()


Consider a text file with the following content:


file1.txt

2 4 6 8 10


How to import file1.txt in R?




Assuming file1.txt is in your working directory:


x <- scan(
  file = "file1.txt",
  what = numeric()
)

x



[1]  2  4  6  8 10

title: Importing Tables
text:
scan() example 1
You can modify the what argument to specify different data types:


x_int <- scan(file = "file1.txt", what = integer())
x_int



[1]  2  4  6  8 10







x_dbl <- scan(file = "file1.txt", what = double())
x_dbl



[1]  2  4  6  8 10







x_chr <- scan(file = "file1.txt", what = character())
x_chr



[1] "2"  "4"  "6"  "8"  "10"

text:
What about file2.txt?



file2.txt

2
4
6
8
10





Assuming file2.txt is in your working directory:


y <- scan(
  file = "file2.txt",
  what = numeric()
)

y

title: Importing Tables
text:
Consider another file named file3.txt



file3.txt

Leia is a 1.50 meters tall female
Luke is a 1.70 meters tall male
Han is a 1.80 meters tall male





By default, scan() expects to read ‚Äúwhite-space‚Äù delimited input fields:



z <- scan(file = "file3.txt", what = character())
z



 [1] "Leia"   "is"     "a"      "1.50"   "meters" "tall"   "female" "Luke"  
 [9] "is"     "a"      "1.70"   "meters" "tall"   "male"   "Han"    "is"    
[17] "a"      "1.80"   "meters" "tall"   "male"

To scan each line at a time, we must change the separator argument from ‚Äúwhite-space‚Äù to ‚Äúnew line character‚Äù, that is: sep = "\n"



z <- scan(file = "file3.txt", what = character(), sep = "\n")

[3] "Han is a 1.80 meters tall male"

title: Importing Tables
text:
About scan()

scan() is R‚Äôs main low-level function to read in data values.
It imports data either into a vector or a list (argument what).
scan() expects to read ‚Äúwhite-space‚Äù delimited input fields by default.
You can change the field separator with sep.
In practice, you won‚Äôt be using scan() that much, instead you‚Äôll use high-level functions‚Äîwhich depend on scan().
But now you know about its basic usage.
See ?scan for more information.

title: Importing Tables
text:
Reading a file, line-by-line
The standard recipe to read the content of a file follows these steps:

Establish a connection (or stream source) with the desired file.
Open the desired file in read mode.
Read each line, and check whether the end-of-file has been reached.
Parse and convert raw string into individual data points.
Close the connection to the file.



In R, pretty much all functions to import data take care of all these steps.
Most of the time you will be specifying arguments related to step 4 to tell R details about the parsing and data conversion.

title: Importing Tables
text:
About "readr"

Provides a fast and friendly way to read rectangular data from delimited files.
Designed to parse many types of data found in the wild.
Gives an informative problem report when parsing leads to unexpected results.
"readr" functions return a tibble instead of a dataframe.

title: Importing Tables
text:
Compared to base R, "readr" functions

Use a consistent naming scheme for the parameters (e.g.¬†col_names and col_types not header and colClasses).
Are generally much faster (up to 10x-100x) depending on the dataset.
Leave strings as is by default, and automatically parse common date/time formats.
Have a helpful progress bar if loading is going to take a while.

title: Importing Tables
text:
Column types and their abbreviations

l: col_logical() (TRUE/FALSE)
i: col_integer() (integers)
d: col_double() (floating-point numbers)
c: col_character() (text, everything else)
D: col_date() (dates)
T: col_datetime() (date-times)
t: col_time() (times)
n: col_number() (numbers with grouping symbols like commas)
f: col_factor() (factors/categorical data)
?: col_guess() (let readr guess the type)
_ or -: col_skip() (ignore the column)

title: Atomic Vectors
text:
Vectors

Central‚Äîand most basic‚Äîdata structure in R
Ordered set of elements (i.e.¬†contiguous cells)
Can be of any length (including zero)
Atomic: elements of the same type
Elements can have names

title: Atomic Vectors
text:
Atomic Vectors

Vectors are atomic structures
The values in a vector must be ALL of the same type!
Either all logicals, or integers, or doubles, or characters
You CANNOT have a vector of different data types

title: Atomic Vectors
text:
Atomic*
Special values in an atomic vector:

NA: Not Available / Missing
NULL: Does not exist (nothing)
NaN: Not a Number (e.g.¬†dividing by zero)
Inf: Infinity

title: Atomic Vectors
text:
A comment about comments
Comment character: special character to skip evaluation of remaining characters on a line. R (and Python) use #.

# create vector
c("A", "C", "D") # vector created!

[1] "A" "C" "D"


vs.

create vector
c("A", "C", "D") vector created!

Error in parse(text = input): <text>:1:8: unexpected symbol
1: create vector
           ^

title: Atomic Vectors
text:
R jargon: Types and Modes

You‚Äôll often see/hear useRs talking about ‚Äúmodes‚Äù instead of ‚Äútypes‚Äù.
The function typeof() returns the type of data: this is how the values are stored internally in R.



typeof(name)



[1] "character"



In S terminology1, instead of talking about types we talk about modes.
The function mode() returns the ‚Äúmode‚Äù of an R object.




mode(name)



[1] "character"



S is the language on which R is based on.

title: Atomic Vectors
text:
Types and Modes







4 main types: logical, integer, double, character
3 main modes: logical, numeric, character

title: Atomic Vectors
text:
Functions to create vectors
R has a large repertoire of functions to create a variety of vectors in different ways.
We‚Äôve already seen the combine function c().
Functions to initialize ‚Äúdummy‚Äù vectors:

logical(length = )
integer(length = )
double(length = )
character(length = )
vector(mode = , length = )

Numeric Sequences with seq()
seq() allows you create numeric sequences of different kinds, for example:


seq(from = 1, to = 5, by = 1)

Numeric Sequences with :
The colon operator : also lets you create simple sequences

The output sequence is produced in 1-unit steps.

Replicates with rep()
rep() replicates the values of the input vector in a handful of different ways:

title: Storms in North Atlantic I
text: Two fundamental spatial data models

title: Storms in North Atlantic I
text:
Two fundamental spatial data models


Vector Data


Raster Data

title: Storms in North Atlantic I
text:
Vector Data





Each row represents one geospatial feature:

a single fire

Attributes describe the features (fields or columns):

name of fire
date of fire alarm
area burned

Each feature has an associated geometry:

polygon

title: Storms in North Atlantic I
text:
Raster Data





Geographic area represented as a grid.
Grid has dimension: fixed number of rows and columns.
A location is represented by a grid cell.
Each cell has a value that represents the attribute of interest: emissions.
Each cell is color-coded based on attribute value.

title: Storms in North Atlantic I
text:
Vector Data
Vector data are better for discretely bounded data, e.g.¬†bike racks, rivers, political boundaries, etc.


Raster Data
Raster data are better for continuous data, e.g.¬†temperature, elevation, rainfall, etc.

Storm geometries (points and lines)


Let‚Äôs see how this map is made.

title: Storms in North Atlantic I
text:
Maps with "ggplot2" and "sf"
Packages:

library(tidyverse)      # includes ggplot2
library(sf)             # simple features
library(rnaturalearth)  # World Map Data


"sf": Simple Features package (for handling vector data in a tidy way)
"rnaturalearth": package that provides World Map data (i.e.¬†vector data sets).

title: Storms in North Atlantic I
text:
Simple Features

A feature is thought of as a thing, or an object in the real world, such as a building, a tree, a bike rack, or a tropical cyclone.
Features have a geometry describing where on Earth the feature is located.
Features can have attributes, which describe other properties.
The Simple Features package "sf" is based on a standard describing how objects located in the real world can be represented in computers.
The Simple Features standard puts emphasis on the spatial geometry of these objects.
The standard is widely implemented in spatial databases such as PostGIS, commercial GIS, and libraries such as GDAL.

title: Storms in North Atlantic I
text:
world1 is an "sf" object:

it is a special data.frame (df with a geometry column)
each row is a feature
each column (or variable) is an attribute
it specifies the Coordinate Reference System: WGS 84
i.e.¬†coordinates are longitude and latitude in Decimal Degrees (DD)
the geometry indicates the kind of vector geometry (e.g.¬†points, lines, polygons)

sf object uses only one type of geometry (not allowed to mix them!)

geometry is used by geom_sf() to plot the corresponding vector geometries

title: Storms in North Atlantic I
text:
Plotting world1 with ggplot() + geom_sf() produces a 2D map.

To be more precise, the LINESTRINGS are projected into a 2D map, which means there is a Projected Coordinate System used by geom_sf() behind the scenes.
By default geom_sf() uses the Plate Carr√©e (equirectangular) projection when plotting data in a geographic system like WGS 84.

title: Unix Basics
text:
GUI
Windows and Mac use a Graphical User Interface (GUI) for you to interact with the Operating System.

title: Unix Basics
text:
About GUIs

Easy to learn
Rely on visual displays
Can be extremely useful
Have improved the friendliness and usability of computers
Excellent for:

Photo editing
Document Layout
Browsing the web
Graphic design
Watching movies
Playing Games

title: Unix Basics
text: Instead of a GUI, you can use a Command-Line Interface (CLI)

title: Unix Basics
text:
CLIs

CLI: Command Line Interface
The command-line is a text-based interface
Instead of using a GUI we can use a CLI
By typing commands we perform tasks on the computer

title: Unix Basics
text:
About the Kernel

The Kernel is the core of the operating system in Unix
It takes care of allocating time and memory to programs
It does very fundamental root level management

title: Unix Basics
text:
About the Shell

The Shell is the outer layer of the OS
That‚Äôs what we see when we open up a terminal window
We are working in the Shell
It interacts with the user and sends requests to the kernel
The Kernel sends results back to the Shell

title: Unix Basics
text:
CLI and Terminal
The command line is a text-based interface where you type commands and direct text-based input and output to the screen, to files, or to other programs.
The Terminal (a.k.a. terminal emulator) is the program that opens a window and lets you interact with the shell.
Often, people blur the distinction between the Terminal and the Shell.

title: The Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot() syntax

ggplot() builds a plot layer by layer, each one added on top of one another with + (not |>).

ggplot() creates canvas
aes() creates mappings, called inside ggplot() or a geom()
geom_() puts down marks using declared geometry




Usually you specify the data in ggplot()
the data must be a dataframe or tibble

title: The Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, 
                     y = flipper_length_mm))

title: The Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, 
                     y = flipper_length_mm)) +
  geom_point()

text:
ggplot(data = penguins,
       mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, 
                     y = flipper_length_mm,
                     color = species)) +
  geom_point()

Facets

facet_wrap() wraps a 1d sequence of panels into 2d

text: Leaflet: Web Interactive Maps

title: Storms in North Atlantic II
text:
Leaflet

library(leaflet)

Leaflet is a JavaScript library used to build interactive maps for websites and web mapping applications.

The R package "leaflet" lets you create and customize Leaflet maps in R.


These maps can be used directly from the R console, Positron, RStudio, in Markdown documents (e.g.¬†qmd, Rmd), and in Shiny applications.

title: Storms in North Atlantic II
text:
Basic Usage
You create a Leaflet map with these basic steps:

Create a map widget by calling leaflet().
Add layers (i.e.¬†features) to the map by using layer functions:

addTiles()
addMarkers()
addCircles()
addPolygons()
addLegend()

Repeat step 2 as desired.
Print the map widget to display it.

text:

leaflet()

title: Storms in North Atlantic II
text:
Map Tiles
Leaflet uses map tiles from:

OpenStreetMap (OSM): https://www.openstreetmap.org/

OSM is simply the database with all the data in xml-vector format.

CartoDB: https://carto.com/basemaps/


You can change the tiles with addProviderTiles(), specifying the provider argument.
See demo gallery at: https://leaflet-extras.github.io/leaflet-providers/preview/

title: Storms in North Atlantic II
text:
Changing Tiles



leaflet() |> 
  addProviderTiles(
    "CartoDB.Positron") |> 
  addMarkers(
    lng = -122.2579, 
    lat = 37.8718, 
    popup = "Fiat Lux")

text:
Changing Tiles

  addProviderTiles(
    "Esri.WorldImagery") |> 
  addMarkers(
    lng = -122.2579, 
    lat = 37.8718, 
    popup = "Fiat Lux")

title: Storms in North Atlantic II
text:
Adding Data Objects
Both leaflet() and the map layer functions have an optional data parameter that is designed to receive spatial data in one of several forms:

From base R:

lng/lat matrix
data frame with lng/lat columns

From the "sf" package:

the data frame of class "sf"

From the "maps" package

the data frame from returned from map()

text:
Mapping Variables to Colors
"leaflet" package provides a couple of functions to generate colors:

colorNumeric(): simple linear mapping from continuous numeric data to an interpolated palette
colorBin(): maps continuous numeric data, but performs binning based on value
colorQuantile(): maps continuous numeric data, but performs binning via the quantile() function
colorFactor(): maps factors to colors (to be used for categorical data)

title: Storms in North Atlantic II
text:
To color code storms based on their name (categorical values) we have to create a color palette via colorFactor().


Unique storm names in 1975:

storms75 |> distinct(name)

# A tibble: 8 √ó 1
  name    
  <chr>   
1 Amy     
2 Blanche 
3 Caroline
4 Doris   
5 Eloise  
6 Faye    
7 Gladys  
8 Hallie  



Rainbow colors:

rainbow(8)

[1] "#FF0000" "#FFBF00" "#80FF00" "#00FF40" "#00FFFF" "#0040FF" "#8000FF"
[8] "#FF00BF"



Color palette function:

pal <- colorFactor(
  palette = rainbow(8), 
  domain = storms75$name)

pal(c("Amy", "Blanche"))

[1] "#FF0000" "#FFBF00"

Storms in North Atlantic II
Storms in North Atlantic II
text:
View Code
storms75 |> 
  leaflet() |> 
  addTiles() |> 
  addCircles(
    lng = ~long, 
    lat = ~lat,
    label = ~paste0(name, ": ", month, "-", day),
    radius = ~wind*1000,
    weight = 1, 
    fillOpacity = 0.7,
    color = ~pal(name)) |> 
  addLegend(
    position = "bottomleft", 
    pal = pal, 
    values = ~name)

text: This is an example of embedding a widget with multiple calendars. This might be useful if you want to have different calendars for assignments, exams, instructor office hours, GSI office hours, etc.

title: Calendar
text: This is an example of embedding a widget with multiple calendars. This might be useful if you want to have different calendars for assignments, exams, instructor office hours, GSI office hours, etc.

title: Calendar
text:
Instructions
We suggest that you delete these instructions before publishing your website.

Create the Calendars:

Go to Google Calendar.
On the left sidebar, click the + sign next to ‚ÄúOther calendars‚Äù and select ‚ÄúCreate new calendar‚Äù.
Create your calendars and name them appropriately.

Obtain the Embed Code for Each Calendar:

For each calendar, go to its settings by clicking on the three dots next to the calendar name and selecting ‚ÄúSettings and sharing‚Äù.
In the calendar settings, scroll down to ‚ÄúIntegrate calendar‚Äù and copy the embed code provided under ‚ÄúEmbed code‚Äù.

Combine the Embed Codes:

Instead of copying the entire embed code, you need the calendar‚Äôs ID, which is part of the embed URL. It will look something like calendarID@group.calendar.google.com.
For example, in the embed URL https://calendar.google.com/calendar/embed?src=calendarID@group.calendar.google.com, calendarID@group.calendar.google.com is the part you need.

Create a Single Embed Link:

Use the base URL for embedding multiple calendars: https://calendar.google.com/calendar/embed?
Append each calendar ID to the base URL using the format &src=calendarID@group.calendar.google.com for each calendar you want to include.
Optionally, you can customize the appearance by adding parameters (e.g., &color=%23F6BF26 for the color, &ctz=America%2FLos_Angeles for the time zone).

For example, if you have two calendars with IDs calendar1ID@group.calendar.google.com and calendar2ID@group.calendar.google.com, your combined embed link would look like this:

https://calendar.google.com/calendar/embed?src=calendar1ID@group.calendar.google.com&src=calendar2ID@group.calendar.google.com

Substitute this URL into the src attribute of the calendar‚Äôs iframe at the top of this page.
